awd_titl_txt: Dielectric Interfaces on Doped Diamond Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical description: Diamond is a crystalline material that shares the same crystal structure with silicon, which has formed the basis of modern electronics.  Recent advances in laboratory growth methods have provided diamond plates suitable for fabricating electronic devices. Compared to silicon, the unique properties of diamond make it the ultimate semiconductor for power and high frequency electronics, where diamond electronics could enable more efficient electronic vehicles, a more efficient and smarter electronic grid, and more efficient communication systems. One of the greatest challenges to advancing diamond electronics is producing dielectric interfaces that can enable fabrication of transistors on diamond wafers. The outcomes of this research provides insight into the electronic properties of dielectric interfaces on diamond for a new generation of high power and high frequency devices. The research provides laboratory training for students to advance the science and technology that will drive this field. This project collaborates with Sundial, a program at Arizona State University which supports retention and diversity in the physical sciences. The activities developed with Sundial include research related workshops and an outreach-level scientific conference, geared to community members and local high school and community college students and teachers. The goals of these activities are to increase access to science careers to students who are traditionally under-represented, by improving retention and educational enrichment opportunities for these students.

Technical description: One of the greatest challenges to advancing diamond electronics is the development of stable, low defect dielectric layers that confine electrons and holes in the conduction and valence band of diamond. This project uses doped epitaxial diamond layers prepared by microwave plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition on single crystal substrates. A unique aspect of diamond is that the surface electron affinity varies by more than 3 eV by controlling the surface termination with H, O or F. A project goal is to determine the electron affinity, band bending, work function, surface Fermi level position and presence of surface states on the p- and n-type diamond surfaces. The well-characterized doped diamond surfaces are used with in situ photoemission measurements to determine the band offsets of wide bandgap dielectric layers on diamond. Three specific layers establish the unique interface properties: i) high work function and high electron affinity oxides (e.g. molybdenum oxide) that have shown unusual surface transfer doping characteristics; ii) water as a dielectric that enables photochemical processes on doped diamond, and iii) ultra-wide band gap fluoride layers that take advantage of the F-terminated diamond surface. The research provides a comprehensive understanding of the band alignment of dielectric layers on diamond and provides guidance for device design.

por.por_cntn:
Diamond has a cubic crystalline structure that is isostructural with silicon. While silicon has supported the development of microelectronics for the last 70 years, diamond has physical properties that could lead to a new generation of microelectronics including power electronics for the electricity grid, high frequency electronics for communications, and quantum electronic sensors. 

The recent development of plasma chemical diamond growth processes, which have been applied to the manufacture of lab grown diamond gems, can also support high purity diamond layers appropriate for microelectronics. The properties of diamond, which would advance microelectronics beyond the applications dominated by silicon, include an ultra wide bandgap that will enable high voltage applications and the highest thermal conductivity of any bulk material that will enable high power electronics. 

While control of the interface of dielectric layers on silicon proved to be the most critical challenge for digital microelectronics, control of the interface of dielectrics on diamond will be equally important for advancing diamond electronics.

The overarching goal of this project has been to develop a comprehensive understanding of the electronic states at the interface of crystalline diamond and dielectric layers. The project combined diamond surface processing, dielectric layer deposition and in situ spectroscopic measurement of the interface electronic states to advance understanding of the diamond ? dielectric interface.

The initial focus of the project was on the interface of aluminum oxide on diamond. The aluminum oxide was selected because it has a bandgap greater than diamond?s and it is stable at high temperature.  The diamond surface was first exposed to a hydrogen plasma followed by the deposition of an ultra thin layer of aluminum oxide (~ 2 nanometers thickness).  The thin aluminum oxide was deposited with atomic layer precision using a plasma technique. In situ electron spectroscopy (i.e. photoemission spectroscopy) was employed to measure the interface electronic states. The in situ spectroscopy enabled development of a process sequence that resulted in an electrically conducting surface layer on the diamond. The aluminum oxide ? diamond interfaces showed a charge density that would be appropriate for amplifying transistor.  Moreover, the electrical properties of the structure were retained after annealing to greater than 400C.  The research was reported in Journal of Applied Physics 122, 155304 (2017).

After careful characterization of the aluminum oxide ? diamond interface, a new approach was proposed to improve the charge mobility of the diamond surface layer. The new approach was based on a concept developed for semiconductors such as GaAs.  The configuration, often termed modulation doping, involve inserting an uncharged interface layer to reduce scattering effects.  Applying this concept to diamond a more complex structure of molybdenum oxide on diamond was tested with and without an aluminum oxide dielectric layer.  The inclusion of a 4 nm aluminum oxide layer between the molybdenum oxide and diamond resulted a 10 time increase in the charge mobility. This result holds great promise for the development of high frequency transistors based on the dielectric ? diamond interface.  The research was reported in Applied Physics Letters 120, 191602 (2022).

Recognizing that the water ? diamond interface has electronic states similar to the dielectric diamond interface, the project established a new approach to employ visible light for photochemistry at a diamond surface. The study employed a nitrogen doped diamond layer on a metal substrate (molybdenum). The surface was processed with a hydrogen plasma, and the structure was immersed in water in a photochemical cell. Illuminating the diamond surface with visible light resulted in electrons injected into the water in a highly reactive state.  The study established that the process could reduce nitrogen to ammonia which is a commercially important reaction. The research was reported as a cover story in Diamond and Related Materials 96, 195 to 197 (2019).

The project directly involved six graduate students and three undergraduate students in the research.  Two graduate students completed their PhD dissertation. All students made presentations at research conferences. Co-PI Zaniewski developed and led ASU Sundial, a bridge program for incoming students that serves students who are at risk of leaving the physical sciences. The research students from the project served as mentors in Sundial, and they contributed to the annual No Jargon Science Conference organized by Sundial. This project also supported mentoring at the national level by sending ASU students to the Access Network assembly, an NSF-funded meeting (2018) to network university-based student support programs. At this assembly, students learn leadership skills, participate in workshops about broadening participation, and network with student leaders from other universities.
